text: At the beginning of the letter, who identifies himself as the author?
options: Jude, a servant of Jesus Christ and brother of James
verseText: Jude, a servant of Jesus Christ and brother of James, To those who are called, beloved in God the Father and kept for Jesus Christ:

text: Regarding the purpose of his letter, what topic did Jude initially want to address before feeling compelled to change?
verseText: Beloved, although I was very eager to write to you about our common salvation, I found it necessary to write appealing to you to contend for the faith...

text: Instead of his original topic, what did Jude find it necessary to urge his readers to do?
options: Contend earnestly for the faith once for all delivered to the saints
verseText: ...I found it necessary to write appealing to you to contend for the faith that was once for all delivered to the saints.

text: What was the primary reason Jude urged his readers to contend earnestly for the faith?
options: Because certain ungodly people had crept in unnoticed
verseText: For certain people have crept in unnoticed who long ago were designated for this condemnation, ungodly people, who pervert the grace of our God into sensuality and deny our only Master and Lord, Jesus Christ.

text: To illustrate the certainty of judgment on the ungodly, Jude reminds his readers of past events. Which group, despite being saved from Egypt, was later destroyed for unbelief?
options: The generation of Israelites who disbelieved
verseText: Now I want to remind you, although you once fully knew it, that Jesus, who saved a people out of the land of Egypt, afterward destroyed those who did not believe.

text: As another example of judgment, Jude mentions beings who abandoned their proper domain. Who are these beings?
verseText: And the angels who did not stay within their own position of authority, but left their proper dwelling, he has kept in eternal chains under gloomy darkness until the judgment of the great day—

text: Which cities does Jude cite as undergoing the punishment of eternal fire for sexual immorality and unnatural desire?
options: Sodom and Gomorrah and the surrounding cities
verseText: just as Sodom and Gomorrah and the surrounding cities, which likewise indulged in sexual immorality and pursued unnatural desire, serve as an example by undergoing a punishment of eternal fire.

text: Jude compares the false teachers infiltrating the church to three specific rebellious figures from the Old Testament. Who are they?
verseText: Woe to them! For they walked in the way of Cain and abandoned themselves for the sake of gain to Balaam's error and perished in Korah's rebellion.

text: Jude references an event from non-canonical tradition involving the Archangel Michael. What was the dispute about?
verseText: But when the archangel Michael, contending with the devil, was disputing about the body of Moses, he did not presume to pronounce a blasphemous judgment, but said, “The Lord rebuke you.”

text: How does Jude instruct believers to respond spiritually amidst the challenges posed by false teachers?
options: By building themselves up in faith and praying in the Holy Spirit
verseText: But you, beloved, building yourselves up in your most holy faith and praying in the Holy Spirit, keep yourselves in the love of God, waiting for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ that leads to eternal life.

text: What attitude and action does Jude recommend towards those who are doubting?
verseText: And have mercy on those who doubt;

text: How should believers interact with those ensnared by the false teachings, according to Jude's instruction?
options: Save them by snatching them out of the fire
verseText: save others by snatching them out of the fire; to others show mercy with fear, hating even the garment stained by the flesh.

text: The letter concludes with a powerful doxology (praise). To whom is this praise directed?
options: God, who is able to keep believers from stumbling
verseText: Now to him who is able to keep you from stumbling and to present you blameless before the presence of his glory with great joy, to the only God, our Savior, through Jesus Christ our Lord, be glory, majesty, dominion, and authority, before all time and now and forever. Amen.

text: To whom is the Epistle of Jude addressed?
options: Those who are called, beloved in God the Father, and kept for Jesus Christ
verseText: Jude, a servant of Jesus Christ and brother of James, To those who are called, beloved in God the Father and kept for Jesus Christ:

text: What relationship does the author Jude claim to James?
verseText: Jude, a servant of Jesus Christ and brother of James...

text: What specific danger prompted Jude to write his letter?
options: The infiltration of ungodly false teachers
verseText: For certain people have crept in unnoticed... ungodly people, who pervert the grace of our God into sensuality and deny our only Master and Lord, Jesus Christ.

text: How are the false teachers described as entering the community?
verseText: For certain people have crept in unnoticed...

text: What distortion of God's grace were the false teachers promoting?
options: That grace was only for a select few
Perverting grace into sensuality (license to sin)
That grace could be earned by works
verseText: ...ungodly people, who pervert the grace of our God into sensuality...

text: Besides distorting grace, what else did the false teachers deny?
options: Their only Master and Lord, Jesus Christ
The authority of the Old Testament
verseText: ...and deny our only Master and Lord, Jesus Christ.

text: What is the ultimate destiny Jude mentions for the angels who sinned?
options: Kept in eternal chains under gloomy darkness
verseText: ...he has kept in eternal chains under gloomy darkness until the judgment of the great day—

text: Jude describes the false teachers based on their actions and attitudes. What do they defile?
verseText: Yet in like manner these people—relying on their dreams—defile the flesh, reject authority, and blaspheme the glorious ones.

text: What do the false teachers reject, according to Jude's description?
verseText: ...reject authority, and blaspheme the glorious ones.

text: What behavior does Jude condemn when he mentions the false teachers 'blaspheme the glorious ones'?
verseText: ...and blaspheme the glorious ones.

text: In the dispute over Moses' body, what did Michael the archangel refrain from doing?
options: Pronouncing a blasphemous judgment against the devil
verseText: ...he did not presume to pronounce a blasphemous judgment, but said, “The Lord rebuke you.”

text: What did Michael say to the devil instead of pronouncing judgment himself?
verseText: ...but said, “The Lord rebuke you.”

text: How does Jude characterize the understanding of the false teachers regarding spiritual matters?
options: They blaspheme what they do not understand
verseText: But these people blaspheme all that they do not understand, and they are destroyed by all that they, like unreasoning animals, understand instinctively.

text: Jude compares the false teachers' instinctive behavior to what?
verseText: ...and they are destroyed by all that they, like unreasoning animals, understand instinctively.

text: What motivated Balaam's error, which the false teachers followed?
verseText: ...and abandoned themselves for the sake of gain to Balaam's error...

text: What rebellion does Jude reference, in which the participants perished?
verseText: ...and perished in Korah's rebellion.

text: Jude uses several metaphors to describe the false teachers. What are they called in the context of fellowship meals ('love feasts')?
verseText: These are hidden reefs at your love feasts, as they feast with you without fear, shepherds feeding themselves...

text: As shepherds, how are the false teachers described?
verseText: ...shepherds feeding themselves...

text: Which natural phenomena are used metaphorically by Jude to describe the false teachers' lack of spiritual substance?
verseText: ...waterless clouds, swept along by winds; fruitless trees in late autumn, twice dead, uprooted;

text: How are the fruitless trees representing the false teachers further described?
verseText: ...fruitless trees in late autumn, twice dead, uprooted;

text: What other chaotic natural images does Jude use for the false teachers?
options: Wild waves of the sea, wandering stars
verseText: wild waves of the sea, casting up the foam of their own shame; wandering stars, for whom the gloom of utter darkness has been reserved forever.

text: What is reserved for the 'wandering stars' (false teachers)?
options: The gloom of utter darkness forever
verseText: ...wandering stars, for whom the gloom of utter darkness has been reserved forever.

text: Jude quotes a prophecy about the Lord's coming judgment. Who does he attribute this prophecy to?
verseText: It was also about these that Enoch, the seventh from Adam, prophesied, saying, “Behold, the Lord comes with ten thousands of his holy ones,

text: According to the prophecy cited by Jude, what will the Lord execute upon his return?
verseText: to execute judgment on all and to convict all the ungodly of all their deeds of ungodliness that they have committed in such an ungodly way...

text: What specific characteristics describe the ungodly people mentioned in Jude's warning?
options: Grumblers, malcontents, following their own sinful desires
verseText: These are grumblers, malcontents, following their own sinful desires; they are loud-mouthed boasters, showing favoritism to gain advantage.

text: How are the false teachers described in terms of their speech?
verseText: ...they are loud-mouthed boasters, showing favoritism to gain advantage.

text: Why do these false teachers show favoritism?
verseText: ...showing favoritism to gain advantage.

text: Jude reminds his readers of predictions made by whom?
options: The apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ
verseText: But you must remember, beloved, the predictions of the apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ.

text: What did the apostles predict would happen in the last time?
options: Scoffers will come, following their own ungodly passions
All nations will turn to God
verseText: They said to you, “In the last time there will be scoffers, following their own ungodly passions.”

text: How does Jude describe the people who cause divisions?
options: Worldly people, devoid of the Spirit
verseText: It is these who cause divisions, worldly people, devoid of the Spirit.

text: What foundation should believers build themselves up on?
verseText: But you, beloved, building yourselves up in your most holy faith...

text: How are believers encouraged to pray?
verseText: ...and praying in the Holy Spirit,

text: What are believers instructed to keep themselves in?
verseText: keep yourselves in the love of God...

text: While keeping themselves in God's love, what should believers wait for?
options: The mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ that leads to eternal life
verseText: ...waiting for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ that leads to eternal life.

text: When showing mercy to some, what attitude should accompany it?
verseText: ...to others show mercy with fear, hating even the garment stained by the flesh.

text: What specific defilement should believers hate even while showing mercy?
options: Even the garment stained by the flesh
verseText: ...hating even the garment stained by the flesh.

text: According to the final doxology, what is God able to do for believers?
verseText: Now to him who is able to keep you from stumbling...

text: How will God present believers before His glory?
verseText: ...and to present you blameless before the presence of his glory with great joy,

text: Through whom is glory, majesty, dominion, and authority ascribed to the only God?
verseText: ...to the only God, our Savior, through Jesus Christ our Lord, be glory, majesty, dominion, and authority, before all time and now and forever. Amen.
